items.content_html:
Bumps @mdn/yari from 2.23.1 to 2.24.0.

Release notes

Sourced from @​mdn/yari's releases.

v2.24.0

2.24.0 (2023-06-05)

Features

  • docs: allow audio (mp3/ogg), video (mp4/webm) and font (woff2) attachments (#7605) (73f8dbc)
  • macros: add GlossarySidebar macro (#8997) (e704315)
  • macros: add XsltSidebar for XSLT pages (#9021) (bddd9f7)
  • placement: hp takeover (#9022) (2ff4a7b)
  • pride month 2023 (#8979) (776e70a)

Bug Fixes

  • constants: add Polish to RETIRED_LOCALES (#8970) (08c15a3)
  • toolbar: reduce height if read-only (#8976) (9e91c72)

Dependabot commands and options

items.title: Bump @mdn/yari from 2.23.1 to 2.24.0

items.content_html:
Description

This PR mainly reworks the figures on the <easing-function> page. It also corrects some phrasings and terms.

Motivation

The issues I found in the figures are that (with decreasing importance):

  1. The existing figures fail to clearly tell which endpoints of segments are included/excluded for the step() group.
  2. Figures (and body texts) use the non-specced terms "time ratio"/"output ratio" instead of "input progress"/"output progress".
  3. Some coordinates are visibly off their correct positions.
  4. Some labels are barely legible due to image compression, which also causes difficulty for l10n (they're too small to be doctored.)

Therefore I replaced and regrouped the figures with SVG ones, and also made the figure style closer to those in the spec.

Additional details

CSS Easing Functions spec:
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-easing/

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Rework figures for `<easing-function>`

items.content_html:
Description

I noticed that the information on the HTML/SVG decoding attribute was somewhat lacking. This PR adds a bit more information and description, to make it clearer what it actually does.

This set of docs could ideally also do with a clear example or two to demonstrate the effect of the different values. I'm currently trying to research and come up with something that demonstrates it in a simple manner.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Adding information about the decoding attribute

items.content_html:
WebRTS statistics may be returned in getStats() methods on the reciever, sender, or peerconnection. The docs are a bit hand wavey about what is returned for senders and receivers - statements like "all streams coming in through the receiver as well as their dependencies". I can't test and I can't tell if, say, a codec or certificate might be a dependency.

What this does is just add a note about the things that are returned for sure. I hope we can expand these at some point with more detail about those dependencies.

These are determined from WPT tests like http://wpt.live/webrtc/RTCRtpReceiver-getStats.https.html
items.title: WebRTC Stats: capture what stats might be in sender and receiver

items.content_html:
These glossary entries are designed to make it easier to talk about setlike and maplike objects, and what APIs might be present in both readonly and read/write versions.

I've listed the items I could find in both types in the appropriate entries.

I also added a comment about the IDL.

Follows on from comment in #27028 (comment)

FYI @wbamberg
items.title: Glossary - new entries for Maplike and Setlike objects

items.title: Fix sample error in autoplay guide

items.content_html:
Description

Make it clearer how min-width and max-width override width , and add a note on how width will still apply to an affected content box if its value remains within the boundaries defined by min-width and max-width.

I don't think information regarding how min-width and max-width override width is clear enough and should be updated to prevent possible confusion with interpretation.

Additional details

I'm a beginner to front-end web development. My interpretation of this small note was that if I use either min-width or max-width, width will never work nor apply to an element's content box when used, so long as either of these attribute declarations apply.

After testing these declarations on:

  • Chromium (Version 114.0.5735.91 (64-bit))
  • Firefox (113.0.2 (64-bit))
  • Microsoft Edge (Version 114.0.1823.37 (64-bit))

I found that min-width and max-width do override width. But width still works if its value is greater than min-width or less than max-width. It's common sense to professional developers, but not to me, as I'm still learning.
items.title: Clarified how `min-width` and `max-width` override `width`

items.content_html:
Description

This PR mainly replaces the example on the createTreeWalker() with two more illustrative ones. It also:

  • updates the spec link of NodeFilter;
  • adds details of the filter parameter.

Motivation

I followed the original example to use only NodeFilter.FILTER_ACCEPT and NodeFilter.FILTER_REJECT for a toy project, but it turns out that NodeFilter.FILTER_REJECT is unexpectedly different from NodeFilter.FILTER_SKIP, the latter of which is not explained on the MDN page.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Replace `createTreeWalker()` examples

Motivation

items.title: typedarray#sort doesn't use string sorting

items.content_html:
The way this combinator works with compound selectors can be confusing and it was a surprise (to me) to see how it actually worked. I think it can easily be misinterpreted with out this specific previous knowledge.

It comes up more when using SCSS transpilation since its more common to throw around the & to refer to the hierarchy.
For example, the following may look like it will match when an element with class .bar follows another element that matches .bar when both are children of .foo but it does not.

.foo {
  .bar {
    & ~ & { ... }
  }
}

Description

I added a note and example for how this combinator handles compound selectors as it seemed non-obvious and important to understand.

Motivation

I came to MDN to find this clarity on how compound selectors were handled by the combinator. I would like to save others some time.

Additional details

n/a

Related issues and pull requests

n/a
items.title: Adding  note for compound selector use cases

items.content_html: The HTML manifest attribute is deprecated, but it's the first result when you search for manifest on MDN. This adds content to tell the user to not use appcache and provides links for what they were probably looking for when they landing on this page.
